title: 106_hr4329
content: Making it illegal to operate a motor vehicle with drugs or alcohol in the driver's body at land border ports of entry. Section 13(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended to make it illegal to operate a motor vehicle with drugs or alcohol at a land border port of entry. This includes consent to chemical tests by Immigration and Naturalization Service officers. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for drug or alcohol testing to determine impairment in individuals operating a motor vehicle. Refusal to submit to the test results in notification to the state or foreign state that issued the individual's license. Convictions for driving under the influence at a land border port of entry are also reported to the Attorney General. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for drug or alcohol testing for individuals operating a motor vehicle at a land border port of entry. Refusal to submit to the test results in notification to the state or foreign state that issued the license. If the individual has no license, the notification goes to the state or foreign state of residence. AUTHORIZING OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE TO CONDUCT TESTS FOR DRUG OR ALCOHOL. Section 287 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow officers at land border ports of entry to conduct breath tests on drivers suspected of alcohol-related offenses under title 18 of the United States Code. If a driver is arrested for operating a vehicle under the influence of drugs or alcohol, the officer may require a breath test to determine alcohol presence or concentration. Officers at land border ports of entry can conduct tests on drivers suspected of alcohol-related offenses under title 18 of the United States Code. If a driver is arrested for driving under the influence, the officer may require a test to determine the presence of drugs or alcohol in the driver's system. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require notices at land border ports of entry about the offense of operating a motor vehicle with drugs or alcohol in the driver's body. The Attorney General will issue regulations allowing the Immigration and Naturalization Service to impound a vehicle if the driver refuses a drug or alcohol test. This Act will take effect 180 days after enactment.
